speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: Do you cry easily, Sam? I mean, when was the last time you cried?

speaker: Sam
text: Let me think… Last week watching a movie, probably. I was watching a really dramatic film and in one scene, the heroine gets separated from her children. I just burst out crying. How about you Neil - when was the last time you cried?

speaker: Neil
text: Men don’t cry, Sam.

speaker: Sam
text: Come on, Neil! That’s a bit stereotypical, isn’t it? – the idea that men don’t show their emotions and women cry all the time.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, that’s an interesting point, Sam, because in today’s programme we’re discussing crying. We’ll be investigating the reasons why we cry and looking at some of the differences between men and women and between crying in public and in private. And of course, we’ll be learning some related vocabulary along the way.

speaker: Sam
text: I guess it’s kind of true that women do cry more than men. People often think crying is only about painful feelings but we also cry to show joy and when we are moved by something beautiful like music or a painting.

speaker: Neil
text: So, maybe women are just more in touch with their feelings and that’s why they cry more. Well actually, Sam, that brings me to our quiz question. According to a study from 2017 conducted in the UK, on average, how many times a year do women cry? Is it:

speaker: Neil
text: b)     72,   or

speaker: Sam
text: Hmm, it's a tricky question, Neil. I mean, there are so many different reasons why people cry. And what makes me cry might make someone else laugh. I think some of my female friends probably cry around once a week, so I‘ll guess the answer is  a) 52.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Sam. We’ll find out later if you were right. Now, while it may be true that men cry less often, it also seems that they feel less embarrassed about crying in public.

speaker: Sam
text: This may be because of differences in how men and women think others will view their public displays of emotion. Here’s BBC Radio 4’s Woman’s Hour speaking to therapist Joanna Cross about the issue of crying at work.

speaker: be taken so seriouslyget a label.final straw
text: Let’s take the workplace. If you’ve got somebody who seems to cry regularly, I think that’s not helpful for the individual because then if they cry over something that really is important to them, they might not be taken so seriously - or they get a label. But I do think crying is often a build-up of frustration and undealt-with situations and it’s a bit of a final straw moment.

speaker: Neil
text: So people who regularly cry at work risk not being taken seriously – not being treated as deserving attention or respect.

speaker: Sam
text: And they might even get a label – become thought of as having a particular character whether that’s true or not. Here’s Joanna Cross again:

speaker: resentmentsweepingbacklog
text: You build up your resentments, your lack of boundaries, not being able to say ‘no’ and then somebody says, ‘Can you go and make a cup of tea?’ and you suddenly find yourself weeping. And everybody says, ‘What’s wrong with her?’ but actually that’s often a backlog of situations.

speaker: resentments
text: So, a common reason for crying at work seems to be a build-up of resentments - feelings of anger when you think you have been treated unfairly or have been forced to accept something you don’t like.

speaker: backlog
text: When left undealt with, these feelings can create a backlog - an accumulation of issues that you should have dealt with before but didn’t.

speaker: weeping
text: Right. And then, like Joanna says, someone asks you to do something very simple and easy, like make a cup of tea, and you start weeping – another word for crying.

speaker: final straw
text: That’s a good example of a final straw moment, a term which comes from the expression, ‘The straw that broke the camel’s back’. The final straw means a further problem which itself might be insignificant but which finally makes you want to give up.

speaker: final straw
text: I hope this programme won’t be the final straw for us, Sam.

speaker: Sam
text: I doubt it, Neil. The only time I cry at work is when you used to bring in your onion sandwiches for lunch. In fact, I can feel a tear rolling down my cheek right now…

speaker: Neil
text: Ah, so that counts as one of your cries, Sam. Remember, I asked you on average how many times a year women in the UK cry – and you said?

speaker: Sam
text: I said a) 52.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, don’t cry when I tell you that you were wrong. The actual answer was c) 72 times a year.

speaker: Sam
text: Which on average is more than men, but less than parents of new-born babies, both mothers and fathers. They cry almost as much as their babies!

speaker: Neil
text: Today, we’ve been talking about crying – or weeping, as it’s sometimes called.

speaker: being taken seriously
text: People who often cry at work risk not being taken seriously – not treated as deserving of attention or respect.

speaker: get a label
text: This means they might get a label – becoming known as someone with a particular kind of personality, even though that may not be true.

speaker: resentments
text: But crying is also a healthy way of expressing emotions. It can help deal with resentments – feelings of anger that you have been treated unfairly.

speaker: backlog
text: If we don’t deal with these feelings in some way, they can grow into a backlog – an accumulation of unresolved issues that you now need to deal with.

speaker: final straw
text: And if you don’t deal with them, you might become a ticking bomb waiting to explode. Then anything someone says to you can become the final straw – the last small problem which makes you want to give up and maybe start crying.

speaker: Neil
text: [Crying]

speaker: Sam
text: What’s the matter, Neil? Was it something I said?

speaker: Neil
text: No, Sam – I’m crying because it’s the end of the programme!

speaker: Sam
text: Ahh, don’t worry because we’ll be back soon for another edition of 6 Minute English. But bye for now.

speaker: Neil
text: Bye.
